content.text: JavaScript 2009 (ES5)

ECMAScript 2009
The first major revision to JavaScript.
ECMAScript 2009 is also known as ES5. 
This chapter describes the new features of ES5.
ES5 Features

"use strict"
  String[number] access
  Multiline strings
  String.trim()
  Array.isArray()
  Array forEach()
  Array map()
  Array filter()
  Array reduce()
  Array reduceRight()
  Array every()
  Array some()
  Array indexOf()
  Array lastIndexOf()
  JSON.parse()
  JSON.stringify()
  Date.now()
  Date toISOString()
  Date toJSON()
  Property getters and setters
  Reserved words as property names
  Object.create()
  Object.keys()
  Object management
  Object protection
  Object defineProperty()
  Function bind()
  Trailing commas
Browser Support
JavaScript 2009 is supported in all modern browsers since July 2013:

Chrome23
  IE/Edge10
  Firefox21
  Safari6
  Opera15


  Sep 2012
  Sep 2012
  Apr 2013
  Jul 2012
  Jul 2013
The "use strict" Directive
"use strict" defines that the JavaScript code should be executed in "strict mode".
With strict mode you can, for example, not use undeclared variables.

You can use strict mode in all your programs. It helps you to write cleaner code,
like preventing you from using undeclared variables.
"use strict" is just a string expression. Old browsers will not throw an error if they don't understand it.
Read more in JS Strict Mode.
Property Access on Strings

The charAt() method returns the character at a specified 
index (position) in a string:

codes.code:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str.charAt(0);            // returns H

content.text: ES5 allows property access on strings:

codes.code:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str[0];                   // returns H

content.text:
Property access on string might be a little unpredictable.
Read more in JS String Methods.
Strings Over Multiple Lines

codes.code: "Hello \Dolly!";

content.text:
The \ method might not have universal support.Older browsers might treat 
the spaces around the backslash differently. Some older browsers do 
not allow spaces behind the \ character.

A safer way to break up a string literal, is to use string 
addition:

codes.code: "Hello " + "Dolly!";

content.text: Reserved Words as Property Names
ES5 allows reserved words as property names:

codes.code: var obj = {name: "John", new: "yes"}

content.text: String trim()
The trim() method removes whitespace from both sides of a string.

codes.code: var str = "       Hello World!        ";alert(str.trim());

content.text: Read more in JS String Methods.
Array.isArray()
The isArray() method checks whether an object is an array.

codes.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];

result = Array.isArray(fruits);

content.text: Read more in JS Arrays.
Array forEach()
The forEach() method calls a function once for each array element.

codes.code:
const numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];

numbers.forEach(myFunction);

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array map()
The map() method creates a new array by performing a function on each array element.
Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array filter()
The filter() method creates a new array from array elements that passes a test.
Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array reduce()
The reduce() method reduces an array to a single value.
Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array reduceRight()
The reduceRight() method reduces an array to a single value (from right to left).
Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array every()
The every() method checks if all array values pass a test.
Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array some()
The some() method checks if some array values pass a test.
Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array indexOf()
The indexOf() method searches for an element value and returns its position.

codes.code:
const fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let position = fruits.indexOf("Apple") + 1;

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
Array lastIndexOf()
lastIndexOf() is the same as indexOf(), but searches from the end of the array.

codes.code:
const fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let position = fruits.lastIndexOf("Apple") + 1;

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.
JSON.parse()
A common use of JSON is to receive data from a web server.
Imagine you received this text string from a web server:

codes.code: '{"name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}'

content.text: The JavaScript function JSON.parse() is used to convert the text into a JavaScript object:

codes.code:
const txt = '{"name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}'

const myObj = JSON.parse(txt);

content.text: Read more in our JSON Tutorial.
JSON.stringify()
A common use of JSON is to send data to a web server.

When sending data to a web server, the data has to be 
a string.
Imagine we have this object in JavaScript:

codes.code: const myObj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};

content.text: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.

codes.code: const myJSON = JSON.stringify(myObj);

content.text: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.
myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:

codes.code:
const myObj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(myObj);

content.text: Read more in our JSON Tutorial.
Date.now()

Date.now() returns the number of milliseconds since zero date (January 1. 
1970 00:00:00 UTC).

codes.code: var timInMSs = Date.now();

content.text: Date.now() returns the same as getTime() performed on a Date object.
Learn more in JS Dates.
Date toISOString()
The toISOString() method converts a Date object to a string, using the ISO standard format:

codes.code:
const d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toISOString();

content.text: Date toJSON()
toJSON() converts a Date object into a string, formatted as a JSON date.
JSON dates have the same format as the ISO-8601 standard: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ:

codes.code:
d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toJSON();

A property setter is a method that allows you to define how a property value is set.

Learn more about Gettes and Setters in JS Object Accessors
Object.defineProperty()
Object.defineProperty() is a new Object method in ES5.

It lets you define an object property and/or change a property's value and/or 
metadata.
Next example is the same code, except it hides the language property from enumeration:
This example creates a setter and a getter to secure upper case updates of language:
Object.create()
The Object.create() method creates an object from an existing object.
Object.keys()
The Object.keys() method returns an array with the keys of an object.
Object Management
ES5 added new Object management methods to JavaScript:
Object Protection
ES5 added Object protection methods to JavaScript:
Function Bind()
With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.
This example creates 2 objects (person and member).
The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:
Learn more in Function bind().
Trailing Commas
ES5 allows trailing commas in object and array definitions:

WARNING
JSON does not allow trailing commas.

codes.code:
//
  Allowed:var person = '{"firstName":"John", "lastName":"Doe", 
  "age":46}'JSON.parse(person)// Not allowed:var person = '{"firstName":"John", 
  "lastName":"Doe", "age":46,}'JSON.parse(person)
